did.abstract: This record group contains the records of the Ann Arbor Symphony Orchestra, the Women's Association for the Ann Arbor Symphony, and partial records for the Michigan Civic Orchestra Association. The record group includes administrative and functional records, photographs, and audio/visual concert recordings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The major corpus of records were donated by the Ann Arbor Symphony (Donor no. 6653) on August 27, 2004.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Ann Arbor Symphony Orchestra Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Ann Arbor Symphony Orchestra began in 1928 as the Ann Arbor Orchestra with only 5 or 6 players. In 1931, the group called themselves the Ann Arbor Community Orchestra and performed their first concert on November 30. By 1935, the orchestra had grown to 40 players, joined with the Ann Arbor Recreation Department, and became known as the Ann Arbor Civic Orchestra.

From 1935 to 1985, the Ann Arbor Civic Orchestra, renamed the Ann Arbor Civic Symphony Orchestra in 1952, provided concerts free of charge to the Ann Arbor Community in area school auditoriums, the Hill Auditorium at the University of Michigan, the Michigan Theater, and the West Park Shell in Ann Arbor's West Park. The Orchestra maintained a commitment to Ann Arbor artists, to encouraging youth involvement in music, and bringing live, classical symphonic music to the city of Ann Arbor. They often teamed with other artistic and musical organizations like the Women's Chorale and the Ann Arbor Civic Ballet. By 1981, the Orchestra had grown to 100 members During this time, the Orchestra had ten conductors, Warren Ketcham (1929-1931), Frederick Ernst (1931-1933), William Champion (1933-1941), Joseph Maddy (1941-1951), Orien Dalley (1951-1955), Emil Raab (1955-1957), George C. Wilson (1957-1961), William Fitch (1961-1963), Emil Holz (1963-1972), and Edward Szabo (1972-1985).

Throughout its history, the A2SO has relied upon the donations of area philanthropists and since 1952, the efforts of the Women's Association. However, starting in the late 1960's and certainly by the 1970's, these monies alone could not keep up with the rising operational cost of the Orchestra. To raise funds, the Orchestra began hosting events to raise both money and awareness of the orchestra. However, the financial problems persisted. In 1985, in a controversial decision that coincided with the somewhat abrupt replacement of Conductor Edward Szabo with Carl St. Clair, the A2SO began charging admission for concerts. This move quickly resulted in a much larger budget from marketing campaigns and ticket sales. The increased budget allowed the Orchestra to attain a higher standard of professionalism, attracting better musicians and soloists, performing more concerts, and bolstering its reputation in Ann Arbor and nationally. Conductors Samuel Wong (1992-1999) and Arie Lipsky (2000-2006) have continued this tradition.

The Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony was formed in 1952 with the goal of assisting with concerts, providing refreshments for players at rehearsals, and raising money both for the Orchestra and for music scholarships for area youth.

The Michigan Civic Orchestra Association began in Ann Arbor in 1939. By 1960, the organization of Michigan orchestras included over 30 community orchestras. It hosted annual meetings and several massed orchestra festivals.

scopecontent.p: The Ann Arbor Symphony Orchestra (AASO) records document the founding and development of the orchestra and the Women's Association for the Ann Arbor Symphony. There are also some records of the Michigan Civic Orchestra Association. The records include administrative and functional records, photographs, and audio/visual concert recordings. The records are arranged into 11 series, History, Board of Directors, Symphony Business, Youth Activities, Fundraising, Publicity, Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony (WA3S) Records, Michigan Civic Orchestra Association, Visual Materials, Scrapbooks, and Audio Materials.

controlaccess.head: Contributors:
controlaccess.corpname: Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony.

scopecontent.p: The History series (0.1 linear feet) contains documents defining the symphony, telling the history, and documenting anniversaries.

The Board of Directors series (0.8 linear feet) functions as an administrative series, including the constitution and by-laws of the board, Meetings and Reports to the Board, Activities of Committees, Financial materials, and Topical files

did.unittitle: Role, Functions and Responsibilities of the Board
Ad Hoc Committee for Youth Soloist Competition 1972
Executive Committee Meeting Minutes and Agendas 1960-1994
Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony 1954-1973

scopecontent.p: Symphony Business (0.3 linear feet) covers the day-to day operations of the symphony, including information about members, and documents relating to rehearsals and concerts. This series corresponds with "Symphony Business" and "Performances" sub-sub-series of Visual Materials, Photographs and with the entire Audio Materials series.

Youth Activities (0.1 linear feet) relates to the interaction between the A2SO and Ann Arbor youth. These include Soloist and Scholarship activities as well as program notes created by the conductor for distribution to area school teachers. From 1986 to 2003, program notes were distributed with the concert programs. This series corresponds with the "Youth" sub-sub-series of Visual Materials, Photographs.

The Fundraising series (0.3 linear feet) documents the work of the A2SO to generate income through contribution, subscription, and later season ticket sales, and major events in the Ann Arbor area. This series corresponds with the "Community" sub-sub-series of Visual Materials, Photographs.

Publicity (0.4 linear feet) includes internal documentation of the efforts for publicity, Symphony Newsletters, posters and other professionally produced promotional material as well as newspaper clippings including advertising, reviews of concerts, and public conversations by letters to the editor.

did.unittitle: Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony Records

scopecontent.p: The Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony (WA3S) Records (0.2 linear feet) document the activities of the Women's Association from 1950 to 1983
The Michigan Civic Orchestra Association series (0.1 linear feet) is a short, incomplete collection of records from the MCOA from 1944 until 1972

The Visual Materials series (1.8 linear feet) is arranged first by format into three sub-series, Photographs, Negatives, and VHS Cassette Tapes. The photographs are further arranged by subject into four sub-sub-series, Symphony Business, including photographs of orchestra members and behind-the-scenes activities, Performances, Community including photographs from fundraising and charitable events, and Youth including photographs of the interaction between the A2SO and the youth of the Southeast Michigan area. Negatives relates directly to the photographs. Most of the VHS Cassette Tapes are recordings of concerts and are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony Donations 11/1983
Sam Wong on Sunday Morning News, Spring 1992
You Should Join the A2 Symphony undated

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks series (1 linear foot), dating from 1931 to 1968, contains a lot of the early documentation of the A2SO, then the Ann Arbor Civic Orchestra or the Ann Arbor Community Orchestra and the Women's Association.

did.unittitle: Women's Association of the Ann Arbor Symphony

scopecontent.p: The Audio Materials series (1 linear foot) contains 112 cassette tapes of concerts from 1974 until 2000.
